noun.description: A financial gain, especially the difference between the amount earned and the amount spent in buying, operating, or producing something.
examples: his eyes brightened at the prospect of profit

verb.description: Obtain a financial advantage or benefit, especially from an investment.
examples: the only people to profit from the entire episode were the lawyers

phrases: fixing up houses and selling them at a profit
By some accounts, that was just a reaction by investors who had anticipated the news, bought early and then sold at a profit.
Brokers, analysts and fund managers around the world spend liberally on research to find hidden gems which they can scoop up cheaply and then sell at a profit.
If you then sell it at a profit, the tax will also be advantageous.
The pre-school is not a business, but a registered charity, unable to operate at a profit, forbidden to do so under laws governing charities.
origin: Middle English (in the sense advantage, benefit): from Old French, from Latin profectus progress, profit, from proficere to advance, from pro- on behalf of + facere do. The verb is from Old French profiter.
